option.value: Creating Engaging Content For Learners – Even For Online Classes

slidelink.displaytext: Creating Engaging Content For Learners – Even For Online Classes
Before we start talking about these topics individually, is there one that stands out? Rank the most important to the least important, in your opinion.
Select Multiple: We covered six main topics today to help you understand your students and boost engagement. What were they?
True/False: Forums can ONLY take place in an online format
Multiple Choice: Which of these is a simple, immediate way to make your lessons more engaging?
True/False: When creating educational content, we should not look as much at what our medium does poorly. Rather, we should focus on our strengths.
Multiple Choice: Which of the options below is a TRUE belief from Andragogy, the study of how adults learn?

search.slidetext: creating engaging content for learners – even for online classes noah kindig
introduction
course overview the big ideas: our online education methods fail, because we treat them like an in-person class. engagement comes from doing, not watching, and the design of the course.

learning objectives for today, our learning objectives are: - online learning can be just as effective as in-person learning, despite what we think - six key topics to increase student retention - strategies to incorporate these ideas for both in-person and online instruction.

assessment: dial in recent years, online classes have only become more prevalent in higher education. what percentage of college classes do you think have some kind of online element? 0% 25% 50% 75% 100%

assessment: slider do you think that online learning is less effective than in-person education, just as effective, or more effective? much less effective just as effective much more effective more effective less effective

answers: coming soon soon, we’ll talk about the answers to these questions, through statistics and polling data. the numbers don’t have to be exact for now, because its important to think about our preconceptions before hopping into our problem.
triggering phase

the problem the current state of online learning is a contrast between desire and reality. although online learning can be just as effective as in-person learning, both students and teachers feel that it is failing (roberts, 2023).

the symptom: engagement if the problem is that we feel that online learning is failing, the symptom of that problem is engagement. we’ve seen spikes in failing grades, and a majority of professors want to increase their own engagement in class.
why engagement? struggling with engagement as a student: my story

survey question (answer here) short answer: why is engaging students so difficult in an online format? think about what makes engaging students difficult anywhere, then what being online adds to that. type answer here

since they are separated from the classroom, online students struggle with little interaction with their fellow students and professors. in an online class, students are often surrounded by distractions such as other electronics, people, or pets. other people or electronics can also help students through the exams or assignments, creating a feeling of not needing to listen. just like with any subject, students can often be uninterested in the subject we are trying to teach. because of the other difficulties listed here, grabbing attention can be even more difficult online. popular answers some of the popular reasons for difficulties engaging students can be seen below. hover over each for more information. difficulties engaging students: uninterested in the subject little interaction distractions and help
survey question (answer here) what are some of the benefits online education brings versus in-person? in other words, why do we use online education in the first place? type answer here

with college becoming more expensive in recent years, students are looking for ways to cut down on costs. whether through e-books or not having to live on campus, online education can save students money, and allow more to attend college. for both students and educators, the ability to learn or grade anytime, anywhere is the biggest advantage online learning offers. maintaining a fill time job while getting a degree is now easier than ever. with the internet at the students’ fingertips as they learn, students are more than ever able to use tools to enhance their own learning. study tools, educational videos, or simple quick answers to questions can help students learn. popular answers some of the benefits online education brings can be seen below. hover over each for more information. anytime, anywhere online benefits price for students more information available
the big idea sample methods to create student engagement for both in-person and online learning. we’ll be looking at six key topics for engagement, and building methods from there.
key terms gamification efficiency interactivity andragogy forum allyship

gamification andragogy forum interactivity allyship efficiency before we start talking about these topics individually, is there one that stands out? rank the most important to the least important, in your opinion. survey: ranking
exploration phase
gamification adding games to your lessons can have several positive effects for your students, but make sure they are necessary!
survey: negatives games can help users get involved in the lesson, but there are times that games are not warranted. can you think of any examples? (text entry) enter text here

playing a game while alone: make sure that your games are geared toward how learners will process information. having someone learning by themselves playing through jeopardy is a lot less engaging than playing with a full classroom or in teams. mix it up: learning successfully requires doing different things, rather than repetitive methods over and over. staring at a textbook and reading the same pages over and over is ineffective, just as playing the same quizlet learning game over and over doesn’t help retain long term information. (brown, 2014) the audience: who do games do best with? a younger audience does better with some games than others, and older learners don’t always enjoy games in their lessons. try to gear your games toward the audience of your lessons. time: games can take a sizeable commitment of time to get everyone set up, play, see who wins, and give out a reward. for a 10 or 15 minute presentation, you might not have enough time, and even in a longer lesson, too many games can take far too long, not allowing you to cover enough material. sample answers click on each icon to see some of the reasons that games might not always be the best solution.

andragogy according to research, adults learn when they need to or when they want to. when we create a situation in which adults wither need to learn or want to learn, we can create engagement (knowles et al., 2020)
forum in it’s simplest terms, a forum is a place that people come together to talk about a given subject. these can be online, or in-person.

don't force it according to research (pavlou, 2021), forums create greater retention and faster learning. this happens because forums share learning. the forums that do best focus on that, rather than forced responses.
assessment: forums what do you think about forums for students, and should instructors have a part in them? should there be a forced forum? (text entry) enter text here
interactivity interactivity overlaps with some of our other topics, such as gamification or a forum. overall, interactivity is about doing something rather than watching (deslauriers et al., 2019).
efficiency when we teach, it’s important to teach without taking up too much time. while removing distractions is good, breaking up learning into smaller portions is better (the tenney school, 2016).

allyship students want to learn from someone they trust, and they succeed, too. a good relationship with a teacher correlates to higher engagement, better grades, and lower dropout rates (sparks, 2019).
integration phase
change weaknesses think about the weaknesses of your method of delivery and focus on correcting them in your education.
the venn diagram our lessons should look like the middle of a venn diagram between in-person instruction and online learning.
assessment: role play to help you be creative in applying ideas from both, we’re going to simulate a conversation between you and a co-worker.
assessment: role play meet charlie, your co-worker. you’ll be helping him engage his students, as you make suggestions on how to improve his lessons.

conversation 1 hey! thanks for agreeing to help me out with this. i’ve been having some trouble recently getting my students to pay attention in class. i know math isn’t always exciting, but i feel like i could do better. what’s going on in your class? why do you think your students don’t pay attention? well, my students have been asking, “when will i need to know this?” for a lot of lessons. they know it will be on the test, but that isn’t enough. so, you need an answer for that question that satisfies your students? maybe… but i think i’m just worried that even if i have an answer for that question, they still won’t think it will be useful. what would you recommend for charlie?

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue allyship gamification andragogy interactivity efficiency drop here drag and drop first: which of our six topics can we apply to this scenario? drag and drop what topics we discussed could be relevant here below. forum
craft a response now that you know which topics you want to tackle, craft a response for charlie to deal with the situation. type response here

conversation 2 hey! thanks for agreeing to help me out with this. i’ve been having some trouble recently getting my students to pay attention in class. i know math isn’t always exciting, but i feel like i could do better. what’s going on in your class? why do you think your students don’t pay attention? i’m teaching a unit on proofs in geometry right now, and my students hate it. it seems like they need something new, but these concepts are too important to move on. so, you need a way to teach to your students in a new way? yeah, i think so. how can i give my students a new way to learn this? i want to find a way to teach this quickly, but make it stick. what would you recommend for charlie?

allyship and andragogy efficiency click and reveal think about which of our six concepts apply to this situation. when you have your answer, click and reveal the boxes below. gamification andragogy forums interactivity allyship efficiency click here click here
craft a response now that you know which topics you want to tackle, craft a response for charlie to deal with the situation. type response here

conversation 3 hey! thanks for agreeing to help me out with this. i’ve been having some trouble recently getting my students to pay attention in class. i know math isn’t always exciting, but i feel like i could do better. what’s going on in your class? why do you think your students don’t pay attention? well, i’m teaching an online class and trying to get students to post on a discussion board, but so many just either don’t post or do the bare minimum for the grade. so, you want to make sure students are getting something out of talking to each other? exactly. but i think i’m just worried that when teaching online, communication like that just isn’t possible. what would you recommend for charlie?

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue allyship gamification andragogy interactivity efficiency drop here drag and drop first: which of our six topics can we apply to this scenario? drag and drop what topics we discussed could be relevant here below. forum
craft a response now that you know which topics you want to tackle, craft a response for charlie to deal with the situation. type response here
sample answers now that you’ve gone through all three conversations, think about your answers. how many different ways did your answers incorporate our topics from today? 1-2 3-4 5-6 7+
resolution phase

assessment to make sure that we take something away from today’s lesson, it’s important to do a low-pressure, final assessment. please click and enter your name below before continuing. your name here

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue andragogy andragogy andragogy andragogy andragogy andragogy gamification gamification gamification gamification gamification gamification leadership leadership leadership leadership leadership leadership allyship allyship allyship allyship allyship allyship communication communication communication communication communication communication forum forum forum forum forum forum efficiency efficiency efficiency efficiency efficiency efficiency interactivity interactivity interactivity interactivity interactivity interactivity discussion discussion discussion discussion discussion discussion assessment assessment assessment assessment assessment assessment select multiple: we covered six main topics today to help you understand your students and boost engagement. what were they?

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue true true true true true true false false false false false false true/false: forums can only take place in an online format

thank you! thank you for your cooperation!

works cited roberts, daniel. “100+ elearning statistics 2023 - facts and stats.” thinkimpact.com, feb. 2022, www.thinkimpact.com/elearning-statistics/#6-elearning-effectiveness. j. hamari, j. koivisto and h. sarsa, "does gamification work? -- a literature review of empirical studies on gamification," 2014 47th hawaii international conference on system sciences, waikoloa, hi, usa, 2014, pp. 3025-3034, doi: 10.1109/hicss.2014.377. brown, peter c. make it stick : the science of successful learning. cambridge, massachusetts, the belknap press of harvard university press, 2014. knowles, m. s., holton, e. f. iii, swanson, r. a., & robinson, p. a. (2020). the adult learner: the definitive classic in adult education and human resource development (9th ed.). routledge/taylor & francis group. https://doi.org/10.4324/9780429 the tenney school, “what is the real ideal class length?” the tenney school, aug. 2016, tenneyschool.com/what-is-the-real-ideal-class-length/. sparks, sarah d. 2019. “why teacher-student relationships matter.” education week 38, no. 25: 8. https://www.edweek.org/teaching-learning/why-teacher-student-relationships-matter/2019/03 pavlou, christina. “online discussion boards: how to engage learners and reinforce learning.” talentlms blog, 23 nov. 2021, www.talentlms.com/blog/online-discussion-boards/.

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

resource.title: Allyship - Why teacher student relationships matter
TED Talk - Learning in the Digital Age

terms.term: Supporting a group without being a member of that group.
The study of teaching adults, or how adults learn.
Doing something well, while also doing it quickly.
A space for discussion between peers.
Applying the elements of a game to other areas of activity.
The ability to get students to react and interact with a given subject.
